courseTitle: Effects of Water Pollution on Microscopic Freshwater Communities

pageData.text: <button class='glossary-text'>Water pollution</button> comes in many forms and can have very different effects on natural populations. In this investigation, students will examine the effects of water pollution on microscopic freshwater communities. Students will manipulate water conditions and assess microorganism populations by counting the numbers of each type of microorganism they find.

pageData.text: Can you tell how polluted water is just by looking at it? There are many different types of pollution in aquatic ecosystems, such as <button class='glossary-text'>nutrient</button> waste from fertilizers, industrial chemicals sewage, plastic, all of which can be seen or detected in a water sample. However, one type of pollution that poses particular harm in aquatic environments cannot be seen or sampled - noise pollution. Because light is limited, especially at lower depths, many aquatic organisms use sound and pressure waves to communicate, find prey, and escape predators.  Whales and dolphins, for instance, rely on sound waves to communicate with one another and use sonar-like signals to navigate through the water. Human-generated sounds can disrupt all these processes. They can also interfere with the development and maturation processes, even causing the fry of some fish to die off before reaching maturity<sup>1</sup>. This harmful noise pollution can come from a variety of sources, but sonar noises and those from oil drilling and mineral extraction are especially loud and likely to affect organisms. And because sound travels faster and better in water than in air, loud noises like these can affect a large number of organisms over a wide area.

1Kunc, H. P., McLaughlin, K. E., & Schmidt, R. (2016). Aquatic noise pollution: Implications for individuals, populations, and ecosystems. Proceedings of the Royal Society B: Biological Sciences, 283(1836), 20160839.
https://doi.org/10.1098/rspb.2016.0839

pageData.desc: A humpback whale jumping out of the water in the foreground. A large boat is in the background.
pageData.altText: A humpback whale jumping out of the water in the foreground. A large boat is in the background.

pageData.text: Fresh water is an essential and vital natural resource. Although it is renewable, the amount of available fresh water at any time is limited. Many human activities affect the water cycle and further limit the water available for human consumption and agriculture. <button class='glossary-text'>Water pollution</button> is defined as any factor that degrades water quality. There are several major types of water pollutants - chemical <button class='glossary-text'>toxicants</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>pathogens</button>, <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button>, radioactivity, physical pollutants, and acidification.

pageData.subTitle: Types of Pollutants Chemical Toxicants
pageData.text: One of the most obvious forms of water pollution are chemical toxicants, such as heavy metals and organic chemicals. Toxicants include natural inorganic chemicals and man-made chemicals that induce disease or death in living organisms at high doses. Conversely, are natural organic chemicals of biological origin that induce disease or death in living organisms. Both toxins and toxicants are toxic for living organisms. Toxicants are common byproducts of industrial processes. These chemicals enter the water system through spillage, rain runoff, and improper disposal. Improper disposal can be from deliberate, illegal dumping of chemical waste into the sewer system, or direct dumping into waterways and storm water drains. Improper release also can be accidental, such as oil spills, leaky storage containers, or poorly maintained landfills and dump sites. Agriculture contributes a significant load of chemical toxicants in the form of pesticides and herbicides as well. Another source of chemical toxicants includes agents such as chlorine that are added to water to remove pathogens.

pageData.subTitle: Pathogens
pageData.text: Pathogens are biological agents of disease such as bacteria, viruses, and protozoans. Many pathogens also produce toxins. The most common source of these organisms is raw sewage, including municipal sewage (originating in cities and suburban areas with primarily human origin) and agricultural sewage (primarily animal origin). In developed countries, most municipal sewage undergoes some form of cleaning or renewal in wastewater treatment facilities or septic systems. However, heavy rains can overload these systems’ raw, untreated sewage into the environment. This is of particular concern for public health because human sewage contains live human pathogens. A growing concern in recent decades is the amount of pharmaceuticals entering water systems through human waste in raw sewage, because there are few mechanisms for their removal and these chemicals pass untreated through water treatment plants and re-enter the drinking water systems. While the concentrations of these substances are currently relatively low, very little is known about the potential consequences of these chemicals for human health. Improper disposal of unused pharmaceuticals also cause these substances to reenter the drinking water system (e.g. flushing unused medicine down the toilet). Industrial farming of cows, pigs, and chickens utilizes enormous amounts of antibiotics and mammalian growth factors. Antibiotics and growth factors not absorbed by the body are excreted, and eventually enter the water systems. The presence of antibiotics in the environment increases the likelihood of emerging. When these strains emerge, they eventually get “used to” certain types of antibiotics from being exposed to them so often, and they become resistant to their effects.

pageData.subTitle: Nutrients
pageData.text: Water is an important agent for dissolving and transporting many <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button> (essential compounds for life) through the environment. <button class='glossary-text'>Eutrophication</button> is a natural, usually gradual process that increases sediment and nutrient availability in water bodies. Nutrient pollution due to an overload of too many nutrients from human activities, however, contributes to <button class='glossary-text'>cultural eutrophication</button>, which involves human-induced activities increasing the speed of this normally gradual process. Raw sewage adds nutrients to waterways. Fertilizer runoff from farms, lawns, and golf courses also contribute to an overload of nutrients that negatively affects aquatic ecosystems. Plant, algal, and bacterial growth in any environment is ultimately limited by scarcity of a particular resource. That resource can be physical, such as light or space, or it can be a nutrient. Very often in terrestrial and freshwater environments, either nitrogen or phosphorous is limiting. Because of this, most fertilizers contain water-soluble nitrogen and phosphorus in the forms of nitrates (NO<sub>3</sub><sup>–</sup>) and phosphates (PO<sub>4</sub><sup>3–</sup>). Rain washes nitrates and phosphates from cultivated land into surface waters, where they promote the rapid growth of plants and algae, which in turn speeds up the rate of eutrophication (Figure 1). Nutrient runoff from lawns, farms, inadequately treated municipal wastewater, and poorly maintained septic systems all contribute to cultural eutrophication. Animal waste adds nitrogen and phosphorus to surface water in agricultural areas with dense animal populations.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: A diagram of the eutrophication process.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram of the eutrophication process.

pageData.text:
This image is licensed under CC BY 2.0 at
https://www.flickr.com/photos/48722974@N07/4859897047

A sudden influx of <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button> into freshwater systems resulting from heavy rains can lead to rapid and uncontrolled population growth of aquatic algae, plants, and bacteria. Microscopic algae increase water <button class='glossary-text'>turbidity</button> and limit light penetration, making it difficult for bottom-dwelling plants to receive enough light and can eventually cause plant death. When the organisms die, they are decayed by bacteria, which deplete oxygen levels and kills sensitive aquatic organisms. This cycle of population growth and subsequent decline contributes to sediment buildup. Nitrogen is the limiting nutrient in most brackish or marine waters, and nitrogen levels ≥ 0.3 parts per million (ppm) can accelerate natural <button class='glossary-text'>eutrophication</button>. Phosphorous is usually the limiting nutrient in fresh water, and phosphorus levels ≥ 0.1 ppm can accelerate natural eutrophication.

pageData.subTitle: Radioactivity
pageData.text: Radioactive contamination of waterways can originate from poorly stored radioactive waste and from accidents at nuclear power plants. This can also occur from accidents during transport of radioactive waste (including medical and biological waste and spent nuclear reactor fuel rods). Water flowing through rocks with high concentrations of radioactive elements can also add to radioactive contamination.

pageData.subTitle: Physical Pollutants
pageData.text: Physical pollution occurs in two primary forms: increased sediment created by runoff from construction sites and agricultural tilling, and thermal pollution. Increased sedimentation can change the course of rivers and increase water turbidity. Turbidity is the cloudiness or haziness of water. High turbidity blocks light from reaching bottom-growing plants and algae and shifts primary production to surface water, which reduces the amount of oxygen produced near the bottom of waterways.

Many industrial processes use water as a cooling agent. Even when the water is not exposed to high levels of chemicals or contaminants, it is often returned to waterways at an elevated temperature that disrupts aquatic ecosystems. At higher temperatures, the amount of gas that can be dissolved in water decreases, which reduces the availability of oxygen to aquatic organisms.

pageData.subTitle: Acidification
pageData.text: Acidification of lakes and rivers can result from mining, improper disposal of industrial acids, or from sulfuric acid entering the waterways. Sulfur dioxide is introduced into the atmosphere primarily from coal-burning power plants. Sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere reacts with ozone to produce sulfuric acid. When sulfuric acid dissolves in rainwater, it lowers rainwater pH, and subsequently lowers the pH of the waterways and soil it flows into. Most aquatic organisms (including fish and amphibians) have evolved and adapted to life within very narrow pH ranges. Large fluctuations in water pH can kill many organisms.

pageData.subTitle: Effects of Pollution
pageData.text: Toxic pollution can decimate entire aquatic communities, while <button class='glossary-text'>eutrophication</button> can produce an opposite, but equally negative effect by stimulating organisms to grow out of control. This causes an imbalance in the cycling of oxygen and <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button> through the system. In some cases, this can result in shifts in the community structure in favor of particular organisms, which exhibit rapid population growth. Organisms less successful at competing with the favored organisms experience population collapse, reducing community diversity and making the community less resilient to further environmental changes. In this activity, students will examine the effects of fertilizer and acidified water on an aquatic community.

pageData.question: Nitrogen is the limiting nutrient in most brackish waters.  At what levels will nitrogen accelerate natural eutrophication?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Nitrogen is the limiting nutrient in most brackish or marine waters, and nitrogen levels ≥0.3 parts per million (ppm) can accelerate natural eutrophication.

pageData.question: Which of the following is a consequence of eutrophication?

options.text: Oxygen levels in the water body are depleted.
The pH of the water body increases.
The populations of aquatic algae and bacteria decline dramatically.
The water body becomes less turbid.
The species in the water body become more sensitive to temperature changes.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Eutrophication initially results in uncontrolled growth of aquatic algae, plants, and bacteria. As these organisms die from limited resource availability, they are broken down by bacteria that deplete the water’s dissolved oxygen as they perform respiration.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A sudden influx of nutrients into freshwater systems resulting from heavy rains can lead to rapid and uncontrolled population growth of aquatic algae, plants, and bacteria. Microscopic algae increase water turbidity and limit light penetration, making it difficult for bottom-dwelling plants to receive enough light and can eventually cause plant death. When the organisms die, they are decayed by bacteria, which deplete oxygen levels and kills sensitive aquatic organisms. This cycle of population growth and subsequent decline contributes to sediment buildup. Nitrogen is the limiting nutrient in most brackish or marine waters, and nitrogen levels ≥ 0.3 parts per million (ppm) can accelerate natural eutrophication. Phosphorous is usually the limiting nutrient in fresh water, and phosphorus levels ≥ 0.1 ppm can accelerate natural eutrophication.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: A sudden influx of nutrients into freshwater systems resulting from heavy rains can lead to rapid and uncontrolled population growth of aquatic algae, plants, and bacteria. Microscopic algae increase water turbidity and limit light penetration, making it difficult for bottom-dwelling plants to receive enough light and can eventually cause plant death. When the organisms die, they are decayed by bacteria, which deplete oxygen levels and kills sensitive aquatic organisms. This cycle of population growth and subsequent decline contributes to sediment buildup. Nitrogen is the limiting nutrient in most brackish or marine waters, and nitrogen levels ≥ 0.3 parts per million (ppm) can accelerate natural eutrophication. Phosphorous is usually the limiting nutrient in fresh water, and phosphorus levels ≥ 0.1 ppm can accelerate natural eutrophication.

pageData.subTitle: Ecological Succession
pageData.text: Many freshwater bodies are ephemeral; they may not exist in drier seasons and may drastically expand after rainfall. To survive in these types of environments, many bacteria and protozoa have evolved to have the ability to form endospores, cysts, or other dormant life stages. These dormant stages have low metabolic activity, are extremely hardy and resistant to changes in extracellular conditions, and may lie dormant for long periods. Dormancy is broken when environmental conditions become favorable, and the organisms become metabolically active and resume their life cycle. This kit supplies a dehydrated mixture containing dead plant material and dormant aquatic organisms. When water is added to the mixture, some of the organisms begin to emerge from dormancy.

The necessary conditions for survival must be met for each organism in a community to thrive (Figure 2). If a <button class='glossary-text'>heterotroph</button> (an organism that depends on other organisms as a food source) emerges before any <button class='glossary-text'>autotrophs</button> (organisms that create chemical energy to supply their own energy and metabolic requirements, usually using energy from the sun), it would starve. Therefore, organisms appear within a community and multiply in predictable patterns based on these needs.

pageData.desc: Figure 2: A food web diagram of the interactions between organisms across trophic levels in a lake ecosystem. There are four rows of organism photos representing trophic levels. From bottom to top, the first row shows primary producers, the second row primary consumers, the third row secondary consumers, and the fourth row tertiary (apex) consumers. Arrows point up from one row to a higher row, representing the flow of energy between trophic levels.Some arrows point to more than one trophic level.
pageData.altText: Figure 2: A food web diagram of the interactions between organisms across trophic levels in a lake ecosystem. There are four rows of organism photos representing trophic levels. From bottom to top, the first row shows primary producers, the second row primary consumers, the third row secondary consumers, and the fourth row tertiary (apex) consumers. Arrows point up from one row to a higher row, representing the flow of energy between trophic levels.Some arrows point to more than one trophic level.

pageData.text:
Aquatic food web by OpenStax is licensed under CC BY 4.0 at
https://openstax.org/books/biology-2e/pages/46-1-ecology-of-ecosystems

Autotrophic bacteria appear first, followed by heterotrophic and autotrophic protozoans, larger heterotrophic protozoans, and finally decomposers or detritivores (organisms that obtain energy and <button class='glossary-text'>nutrients</button> from breaking down dead material). As these communities develop, some organisms will be favored over others, depending on the environmental conditions. Optimal conditions for a particular organism define its <button class='glossary-text'>ecological niche</button>. Which organisms will be favored in each environment will depend on which organisms are best suited to compete for the available resources; those that occupy an ecological niche that is most compatible with the conditions in the environment. Over time, given differing starting conditions, very different cultures may emerge. This phenomenon of change in ecological niches and the emergence of dominant organisms based on conditions within an ecosystem is known as <button class='glossary-text'>ecological succession</button>.

pageData.question: What phenomenon occurs during an ecological succession?

options.text: Some species grow while other species decline.
All species grow at the same rate.
Only species that are autotrophs survive.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Ecological succession is the gradual change in the species composition of a given area which can be predicted.  During ecological succession, some species colonize and grow while species decline or disappear.

pageData.question: Which of the following types of organisms is usually the last to appear within a community?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Decomposers, or detritivores (organisms that obtain energy and nutrients from dead material) are the last to appear within a community.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The necessary conditions for survival must be met for each organism in a community to thrive. If a heterotroph (an organism that depends on other organisms as a food source) emerges before any autotrophs (organisms that create chemical energy to supply their own energy and metabolic requirements, usually using energy from the sun), it would starve. Therefore, organisms appear within a community and multiply in predictable patterns based on these needs. Autotrophic bacteria appear first, followed by heterotrophic and autotrophic protozoans, larger heterotrophic protozoans, and finally decomposers or detritivores (organisms that obtain energy and nutrients from breaking down dead material). As these communities develop, some organisms will be favored over others, depending on the environmental conditions. Optimal conditions for a particular organism define its ecological niche. Which organisms will be favored in each environment will depend on which organisms are best suited to compete for the available resources; those that occupy an ecological niche that is most compatible with the conditions in the environment. Over time, given differing starting conditions, very different cultures may emerge. This phenomenon of change in ecological niches and the emergence of dominant organisms based on conditions within an ecosystem is known as ecological succession.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before beginning, set up your cups with water and pond mix, add fertilizer to the eutrophication cup, and measure the initial volume. Then, make a grid on the slide.  In activity 1, you will mix the cultures with a pipet and bubble air through the mixture each day for 10 days. If the volume decreases on any of these days, add water up to the volume line. On even days, you will also observe the cultures by adding a drop of culture to the microscope slide. Then, add ProtoSlo to the slide, cover the slide, and observe it under the microscope. Next, you will draw, identify, count, and photograph the organisms on the slide. Then, you will wash and reset the slide. Once you have observed all 3 cultures under the microscope, replace the cultures so that they can be observed the next day.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following lists describes some major types of water pollution?
What is the difference between toxicants and toxins?

options.text: Toxicants are inorganic chemicals; toxins are organic chemicals of biological origin.
Toxicants are organic chemicals of biological origin; toxins are man-made.
Toxicants do not cause disease or death; toxins induce disease and death in living organisms.
Toxicants cause disease and death at high doses; toxins do not cause disease or death.
Toxicants cause disease and death at high doses; toxins cause disease and death at low doses.

assestmentData.question: What is the most common source of pathogens?
Terrestrial and freshwater environments often have limited quantities of which nutrients?
Which of the following materials will you need to provide yourself to complete this investigation?
What ratio of bleach to water do you need to make a 10% bleach solution for this investigation?
Sulfur dioxide in the atmosphere reacts with which of the following compounds to produce sulfuric acid, ultimately lowering the pH of rainwater?
Which of the following is NOT a common contributor to eutrophication?

options.text: fertilizer runoff from farms and lawns

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result

You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.

To perform this investigation, select an area where the water samples can remain undisturbed for 10 days (this area should not be accessible to children or pets). The area should receive bright, indirect sunlight.
Remove 3 plastic cups from the equipment kit. Using the permanent marker, label each with one of the following: “Control,” “Eutrophic,” or “Acid Rain.”
Place two spoonfuls of Carolina<sup>®</sup> Pond Mystery Mix in each cup.

Measure 200 mL of bottled or spring water with a graduated cylinder and add it to the container labeled “Control.” Measure an additional 200 mL of bottled or spring water and add it to the container labeled “Eutrophic.”
Measure 200 mL of the simulated acid rain with the graduated cylinder and add this to the container labeled “Acid Rain.”
Ensuring you are wearing all PPE, open the fertilizer packet and count out 10 grains of fertilizer. Add this fertilizer to the container labeled “Eutrophic.”

Select 3 transfer pipets and use a separate transfer pipet to stir each culture (do not cross-contaminate the pipets). Either leave each pipet in the container, or label it to match the culture sample and keep the pipets separate for later use.
Mark the side of each cup with the marker to indicate the starting volume. Place the cups in a location that gets bright, but indirect sunlight.

Using the ruler and permanent marker, create a 1.5 x 1.5 cm grid on the center of your microscope slide with 0.3 cm (3 mm) markings (Figure 3). Set the slide aside in a clean and undisturbed location.

pageData.desc: Figure 3: A gloved hand holding a microscope slide with a 1.5 x 1.5-centimeter grid drawn on it with 0.3-centimeter grid markings.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: A gloved hand holding a microscope slide with a 1.5 x 1.5-centimeter grid drawn on it with 0.3-centimeter grid markings.

pageData.text: In Activity 1, you will set up cultures testing the effects of acid rain and <button class='glossary-text'>eutrophication</button> on pond microorganisms over the course of 10 days. On even days, you will observe samples from each culture under the microscope, identifying and counting the microorganisms you observe.

pages.title:
A
 Effects of Water Pollution on Microorganisms (16 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Effects of Water Pollution on Microorganisms (16 steps)

pageData.text: Each day, stir the mixtures with the pipet designated for that culture.

While stirring each mixture, bubble air through the solution several times by squeezing the bulb of the pipette. If any solution is withdrawn into the pipet, ensure that it is returned to the mixture.

Check the mark you made on the cup to indicate that starting volume. If the level is noticeably lower (due to evaporation), add a small amount of bottled or spring water to bring the total volume back up to the starting volume. Ensure that all cultures have the same volume as the starting volume.

Observe each culture. Starting with the “Control” culture, record your general observations for the corresponding day in Data Table 1. Hold a sheet of paper with text behind the culture and observe the of the culture solution. Record your observations in Data Table 1.
Place the microscope slide with the grid on a flat surface. Place the grid side face-down so that the unmarked side of the microscope slide is facing up.

Using the proper pipet, stir the “Control” culture. Draw up a small volume of the “Control” culture into the pipet, and place one small drop on the unmarked side of the microscope slide as shown in Figure 4 (red circle). Return the pipet to the culture.

pageData.desc: Figure 4: A microscope slide with a 1.5 x 1.5-centimeter grid; a red circle and a black circle are in the middle, indicating a culture sample drop and a Protoslo drop, respectively.
pageData.altText: Figure 4: A microscope slide with a 1.5 x 1.5-centimeter grid; a red circle and a black circle are in the middle, indicating a culture sample drop and a Protoslo drop, respectively.

pageData.text: Add one small drop of ProtoSlo™ next to the culture sample drop on the slide as shown in Figure 4 (black circle).
Holding a coverslip along its sides, place one edge on the slide just next to the culture drop, so that you are holding the coverslip at a 45-degree angle to the microscope slide.
Slowly lower the coverslip, allowing the culture drop to spread out and mix with the ProtoSlo™.

Once the coverslip is in place, blot any extra fluid around the coverslip with a small piece of paper towel. Do not hold the paper towel adjacent to the coverslip because it could wick some of the sample away from underneath the coverslip.
Place the slide under your microscope.

Examine the different types of organisms you observe. Make a drawing of each organism type on a sheet of paper. You will photograph this drawing sheet for submission in the Lab Notebook. You may not have very many organisms during the first days of the experiment. If your instructor advises you to do so, use the Identification to help you identify the organisms.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.desc: Figure 5: A microscope slide with a 1.5 x 1.5-centimeter grid that shows alternating blue arrows pointing up and down each row on the grid.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: A microscope slide with a 1.5 x 1.5-centimeter grid that shows alternating blue arrows pointing up and down each row on the grid.

pageData.text: Using the grid as a guide, methodically scan through the sample (Figure 5). Count the numbers of each type of organism you observe in the “Control” culture sample and record these data into the appropriate rows in Data Table 1. On Days 2, 6, and 10, take a photograph through the microscope of grid that contains a few organisms.
pageData.desc: camera symbol
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: When you finish collecting data for the sample, remove the coverslip. Gently but thoroughly rinse and dry the coverslip and microscope slide with bottled or spring water.
Caution: The coverslip is very thin and fragile and breaks easily. Broken coverslips are sharp and can cut your fingers. Use extreme caution when working with the coverslip and microscope slide.

If some of the grid markings are washed off the microscope slide, redraw the grid as instructed in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 3</button>. Always place the culture sample on the unmarked side of the slide.

Repeat Steps 1–12 for the “Eutrophic” and “Simulated Acid Rain” cultures, recording your data in Data Tables 2 and 3, respectively. Remember to use only the dedicated pipet associated with each culture to stir and dispense the sample.
Add 20 mL of household bleach to each culture. Allow this to stand for 4 hours.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Pour off the liquid from each culture into a drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for 3 minutes to dilute the solution.
pageData.desc: stopwatch symbol
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

text: 1. Rinse the equipment from the equipment kit with tap water, allow to dry, and return the materials to your equipment kit. Throw away all other materials from the materials kit in the household trash.

text: Did the communities in each culture differ from one another? How?

Communities are frequently characterized by their diversity. Diversity is usually expressed as total species richness, the number of species found in an area. Evenness, whether the numbers of individuals in various populations are similar, also affects functional diversity of a community. Since estimates of species richness (S = total number of species) are highly dependent on sampling effort, species diversity is frequently reported relative to the total number of individuals sampled. The appropriate technique to use in creating such indices has been the subject of much scientific debate. Two commonly used indices are the Shannon index (also called the Shannon-Weiner or Shannon-Weaver index), which measures species richness, and the Simpson index, which is a measure of diversity. In both cases, pi is the proportion of a species in the community (the counted number of individuals of a given species divided by the total number of individuals counted for all species in the community).

pageData.desc: Equation

pageData.text: Use your collected data to calculate one of these measures of diversity for each of your cultures. How do they compare?

text: Every year, a large anoxic/hypoxic zone (a region with low or absent oxygen) develops in the summer in the Gulf of Mexico, adjacent to the Mississippi River Delta. This area then expands along the coast of Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Texas. Why do heavy spring rains cause this hypoxic region to intensify and expand?

Residents of a picturesque town on a lake rely on summer income from recreational fishermen. The townspeople notice a die-off of lake trout and hire you to determine the cause of the fish kill. As you investigate, you make several observations: an increasing amount of algae in the lake, the presence of an industrial facility in a cove of the lake, and a dairy farm upstream of the lake. In a detailed paragraph, address how you would proceed in determining the cause of the fish kill, and describe other evidence you would need before drawing any conclusions.

Consider the following scenario. Environmental concerns are growing about the water quality of a local stream that runs near a hog farm. Students have decided to test the water at various sites. Site A is upstream from the hog farm, Site B is located within the hog farm, and Sites C, D, and E are all downstream from the farm. The collected data are presented in this table.

pageData.text: On the basis of these data, what is the likelihood that hog waste is affecting water quality? Defend your argument.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: A diagram of the eutrophication process.

Figure 2: A food web diagram of the interactions between organisms across trophic levels in a lake ecosystem. There are four rows of organism photos representing trophic levels. From bottom to top, the first row shows primary producers, the second row primary consumers, the third row secondary consumers, and the fourth row tertiary (apex) consumers. Arrows point up from one row to a higher row, representing the flow of energy between trophic levels.Some arrows point to more than one trophic level.

A map of the procedural workflow of this investigation. To prepare, you will fill the tray with sand, soak and level it and allow it to harden overnight. In Activity 1, you will slope the tray using a book. Then, you will pour water down the slope of sand from a cup. Next, you will observe and photograph the steam, measure its dimensions and calculate the physical stream values. You will repeat this for 3 trials, then change the slope of the tray by using a different book. You will repeat the process for 3 more trials at this height.  In activity 2, you will design a new procedure testing the effect of a new variable on stream formation. Then you will form a hypothesis and perform 3 trials of your experiment.

data.title: Antibiotic-resistant bacterial strain
data.content: A strain of bacteria that is resistant to antibiotics

data.title: Autotroph
data.content: An organism that creates chemical energy to supply their own energy and metabolic requirements

data.title: Ecological niche
data.content: The role or job of an species in a habitat

data.title: Ecological succession
data.content: The change in species structure in an ecosystem over time

data.title: Eutrophication
data.content: A natural process that increases sediment and nutrient availability in water bodies

data.title: Heterotroph
data.content: An organism that depends on other organisms as a food source

data.title: Pathogen
data.content: A biological agent of disease, such as a bacterium, virus, or protozoan

data.title: Toxicant
data.content: A natural inorganic chemical or man-made chemical that induces disease or death in living organisms at high doses

data.title: Toxin
data.content: A natural organic chemical of biological origin that induces disease or death in living organisms

data.title: Turbidity
data.content: The cloudiness or haziness of water due to suspended particles

data.title: Water pollution
data.content: Any factor that degrades water quality
